docs.abstract: North Korea says it has detonated its first hydrogen bomb, claim that, if proved true, would significantly increase threat from dangerous and isolated nation; detection devices measured 5.1 seismic event near North Korean coast, but it may be weeks or months before United States and allies can confirm nature of test.

headline.main: North Korea Says It Has Detonated Its First Hydrogen Bomb

byline.contributor: David E. Sanger reported from Washington, and Choe Sang-hun from Seoul, South Korea. Jonah Bromwich contributed reporting from New York.

docs.snippet: U.S. presidential candidates and members of the U.S. Congress demanded more sanctions on North Korea on Wednesday after its latest nuclear test, but major powers will likely be reluctant to take the tough steps necessary to force Pyongyang to aban...
docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. presidential candidates and members of the U.S. Congress demanded more sanctions on North Korea on Wednesday after its latest nuclear test, but major powers will likely be reluctant to take the tough steps necessary to force Pyongyang to abandon its weapons program, former U.S. officials and analysts said.

headline.main: North Korea Nuclear Test Poses Sanctions Dilemma for Major Powers
headline.print_headline: North Korea Nuclear Test Poses Sanctions Dilemma for Major Powers

docs.snippet: The United States, South Korea and Japan agreed to launch a "united and strong" international response to North Korea's apparent fourth nuclear test, as experts scrambled Thursday to find more details about the detonation that drew worldwide skept...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States, South Korea and Japan agreed to launch a "united and strong" international response to North Korea's apparent fourth nuclear test, as experts scrambled Thursday to find more details about the detonation that drew worldwide skepticism and condemnation.

headline.main: US, S. Korea and Japan Vow Tough Response to N. Korea
headline.print_headline: US, S. Korea and Japan Vow Tough Response to N. Korea
